utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I recently read that during World War Two, Joseph Stalin had a research program to create supersoldiers by having women impregnated by gorillas.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: What a sick use of science.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Hey, as long as the baby’s healthy.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I wonder if Stalin considered any other animals.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hippos are the deadliest creature. A half-human, half-hippo soldier would be pretty badass.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yes, but when they’re hungry-hungry, you can stop them with marbles.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, the correct animal for interspecies supersolider is koala. You would wind up with an army so cute it couldn’t be attacked.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: But half-man, half-owl could fly…

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: The answer is cuddly soldiers with big flat noses. Moving on.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: So, Penny, when’s the new job start?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Next Monday.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Did you get a chance to look over the materials I gave you?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Uh, not yet, but I will.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Great. When?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I said I’ll get to it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m sensing awkwardness, am I right?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Swish.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I don’t want to be pushy, but you’ve never done pharmaceutical sales before. It seems like you could use this time to get a head start.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, the first few weeks will be all training. They’ll tell me everything I need to know.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: But imagine how impressed they’d be if you showed up already familiar with the material.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, so what, you want me to be like a teacher’s pet?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Couldn’t hurt.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Mm, I don’t know. Who here has ever been hurt because they were the teacher’s pet?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It was like the rest of the class wanted Ms. McDonald to forget the quiz.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Mrs. Davis. Guess who?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Davis
utterance.content: Dr. Cooper.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That’s right, good job. Hello. Uh, you wanted to see me?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Davis
utterance.content: Yes. Uh, welcome back.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Thank you. I assume you’d like to reopen our dialogue about the university forcing me to continue with string theory?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Davis
utterance.content: You mean the dialogue that went, please, no, please, no, please, no.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That’s the one. I believe you went last, so, uh, please?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Davis
utterance.content: Dr. Cooper, while you were away, we came up with a solution that would allow you to change your field of study.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Wow. Pouting and running away actually worked. I must say, that may not be a lesson you want to reinforce with me. So, um, what is the solution?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Davis
utterance.content: Currently, you’re being paid under a grant to specifically research string theory. If we promote you to junior professor, you’ll be able to choose whatever field of research you’d like.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: But if I’m a professor, then I’ll have to teach a class.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Davis
utterance.content: That is correct.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: So your solution is to promote me and pay me more money so that I can impart my knowledge to the next generation of scientists?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Davis
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You people are sick.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hey. Ready to go to lunch?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Just give me a minute. I’m stimulating the pleasure cells of this starfish. I just need to turn it off.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What happens if you don’t?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Then I have to sit through lunch knowing this starfish is having a better day than I am. Is Bernadette meeting us at the restaurant?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Uh, no. Actually, I didn’t invite her.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: How come?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, ever since she helped me get this job, she won’t stop bugging me.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Well, I think she just wants you to do well, and she’s worried that you won’t ’cause you were just a stunningly poor waitress.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: That is not true.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I’m still waiting on my mini corndogs from two years ago.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I told you, they’ll be right out.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Okay, so no Bernadette.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, you saw her the other night. Am I wrong?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: No, I just, I feel kind of uncomfortable talking about her like this. Usually when someone’s being talked about behind their back, it’s me and it’s right in front of my face.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I’m sorry. I just need a little break from her.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I understand. You know, there is some research that indicates that sharing negative attitudes about a third party can be a powerful bonding force between two friends.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: So, what are you saying?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I’m saying, in the spirit of science, what is that little skank’s problem?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: So, I’ve been trying to come up with a cute couple’s nickname for me and Emily. What do you like better? Emippali or Koothrapemily?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Why is it your last name and her first name?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh, well, her last name is Sweeney, and something just didn’t seem right about Koothrapeeney.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey, how’d it go with human resources?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Awful. They’re allowing me to move on from string theory, but they made me a junior professor and are requiring me to teach a class.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I don’t understand. Why is it bad that you have to teach?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What a stupid question.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: The kids are gonna love him.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I can’t believe I have to waste my time babysitting a bunch of grad students who probably think dark matter is what’s in their diapers.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: This might not be that bad. Uh, you like telling people they’re wrong.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Wrong, Just because I enjoyed that one doesn’t mean I always do.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: You enjoy giving people grades.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: A valid point, but unoriginal. B-minus.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: And you love the sound of your own voice.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, well, of course I do. Listen to it. It’s like an earful of melted caramel.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Look, most importantly, this will let you move on and study dark matter.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It is true that many of my heroes have taken students under their wings. Feynman, Einstein, Professor X. Humorously, in the case of Professor X, some of his students actually had wings. That’s rich. I’ll use that one to lighten the mood after my entire class fails the midterm.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Measuring starfish serotonin levels in response to one point two molar stimulation of pleasure cells. You like that, don’t you? That’s right, say my name.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette (on skype)
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Hey, what’s going on?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Not much. You want to get a drink later? Just the two of us?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: No Penny?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Not tonight. I’m a little frustrated with her.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Because you got her the job and you think she should be working harder to prepare for it?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: So it’s not just me. You see it, too.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I do, I see it.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: It’s driving me crazy. Just this afternoon, I saw on Instagram that instead of studying, she went out to lunch and got a manicure.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: That’s outrageous.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I know.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: If she doesn’t do well, this could reflect poorly on you.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Exactly. Does she not realize it or does she not care?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I don’t know. The important thing is I am here for you so we can mutually disparage this unpleasing third party.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey. We just wanted to see how your class was going. Where is everybody?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: There is no class.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Did you send everyone to the principal’s office already?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No one signed up.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, that’s not your fault.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I called the department secretary to see what happened. Apparently, I have a reputation for being obnoxious.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Hey, Sheldon, I’m sorry.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, it’s fine. Now I can devote all my time to dark matter.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Aw, you brought cookies for everyone?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, yes. Fig Newtons. I was going to ask them which scientist both helped to develop calculus and had a famous cookie named after him? And then after someone said Newton, I was going to tell them they’re wrong. The cookies are named after a town in Massachusetts. And then I’d throw the cookies away.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hey, what if I took your class?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Why would you do that?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, why would you do that?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: What’s wrong with you?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I’m thinking about getting my doctorate, and he wants to teach. Why not?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, Howard. I appreciate the gesture, but this is a graduate-level physics class. I don’t think you’d understand a single thing I was talking about.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Ask why not again, I’ve got an answer.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Sheldon, I’m more than smart enough to take your class.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: How would you determine the ground state of a quantum system with no exact solution?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I would guess a wave-function and then vary its parameters until I found the lowest energy solution.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hmm. Do you know how to integrate X squared times E to the minus X, without looking it up?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I’d use Feynman’s trick, differentiate under the integral sign.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Okay. Um, what is the correct interpretation of quantum mechanics?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Since every interpretation gives exactly the same answer to every measurement, they are all equally correct. However, I know you believe in the Many Worlds Interpretation, so I’ll say that. Now do you think I’m smart enough?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh, come on. You might’ve gone to school for a couple more years than me, but guess what, engineers are just as smart as physicists.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You take that back.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: So, after drinks with Bernadette, I get home, and Penny calls to complain about her. And then while I’m talking to Penny, I get a text from Bernadette.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I am trying to prepare my lesson plan for Howard. Why are you telling me this?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Because it’s taken 15 years, but high school is finally awesome. I love them both, but I’m in the centre now, and I love that even more.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Amy, please. I am trying to figure out a way to intellectually emasculate a dear friend of mine.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: But I’m just…

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Not now.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: You better watch that attitude, buddy. You’re dating the popular girl now.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hmm. You’re up late.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, I’m working on my lesson plan for Wolowitz. He is going to be so lost. Look at this section over here. Even I don’t really understand it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, why are you doing this?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m a teacher, Leonard. It’s my job.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, I mean, why are you going to so much trouble to prove that you’re smarter than Wolowitz?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, it’s no trouble, it’s actually a pleasure.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You want to know what I think? I think the idea that someone could be as smart as you, or even smarter, scares the pants off you, and you can’t deal with it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Interesting point. You’re suggesting that I have emotional issues below my consciousness which drive my behaviour, thus causing me to lash out at anything or anyone that threatens my intellectual superiority.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Might be something to think about.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Leonard?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Howard’s allergic to peanuts. How can I use that against him?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Okay, now that everyone’s here, we can begin.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Before we do, I just talked to Leonard. And if you’re gonna spend all your time trying to belittle me by making this class unnecessarily hard, then I’m out. But if you’re interested in making a sincere effort to be a good teacher, then I’m willing to give this a shot.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I suppose that’s a fair request. There’s no reason we both can’t benefit from this experience.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Okay. Well, then, uh, first things first. Um, are you familiar with the Brachistochrone problem?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I am.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Good. And how it relates to the calculus of variations?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: It’s an inverted cycloid.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Wonderful. Now, what about Euler-Lagrange theorems?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: That’s where I’m a little fuzzy.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Ha! I knew it. All right. We have a lot of information to cover before your first test. Which, by the way, is in eight minutes. The good news is I’m grading on a curve, so you’re pretty much guaranteed a C.

utterance.speaker: Howard (singing)
utterance.content: All I do is win, win, win no matter what.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: Howard (singing)
utterance.content: Everybody hands go up, up and they stay there!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: If you’re gonna be a crappy teacher, then I’m gonna be a crappy student. Uh, uh, Ludacris going in on the verse. ’cause I never been defeated and I won’t stop now…

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Will you stop it. This is a classroom. This is not American Bandstand.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Now, where was I? Let’s see. Oh, yes. Over here. You… What are you doing now?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Making a straw.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: So I can shoot you with a spitball.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You’re not going to do that, and I’ll tell you why. This is an institution of higher learning, I am your professor, and you’re going to treat me with the prop… You shot your spit in my mouth!

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Is that gonna be on the test? Because I don’t think I can do that again.

utterance.speaker: Amy (on phone)
utterance.content: Hey, girlfriend. Can I get a what what?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Close enough. Um, I was just calling to see what you were up tonight. Thought maybe we could hit up Color Me Mine, maybe sneak in some Pinot Greej. Whatevs.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Uh, thanks, but I think I’m gonna stay in and go over the stuff Bernadette gave me.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Oh. Oh, I hear you. Try and get that nag off your back, right? I mean, you’re not a bicycle, why’s she riding you like that?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No, I think she was just trying to help. Plus, I really want to do well at this job. So…

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Okay, good luck. And call me later, you know, if you decide she’s a bitch or something. Hey, girlfriend.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Hey, Amy.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Tonight. You, me, Color Me Mine. Maybe we sneak in some Pinot, make it Color Me Wine.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: That sounds fun, but I promised Penny I’d come by and help her study.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Oh. Well, good luck getting her to do that. She’s probably off getting another manicure. You remember when she did that? You remember?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I was probably being too hard on her. We talked, we’re good.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Oh. Great. I’m happy for you guys. You know, when the two of you aren’t getting along, it puts me in a really weird position.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Well, don’t worry, everything’s back to normal.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: You mean, like, where she’s nice to your face? Okay got it. Bye. Hey, boyfriend.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Can’t talk. Spitball. Probably gonna die.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, I promise. Your uvula does not have an STD.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Are you sure? It just doesn’t feel as innocent as it used to.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You reported me to human resources?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You violated the sanctity of my mouth.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Well, I dropped your class, so I hope you’re happy.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I told you you weren’t smart enough to take it.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I’m smart enough, Sheldon. Asking me a bunch of questions about a topic I’m not familiar with doesn’t prove anything. I could do the same to you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, try me.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay. You enjoy making fun of engineering so much, how do you quantify the strength of materials?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Young’s modulus.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Is that right?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah. Okay, how do you prevent eddy currents in a transformer?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Laminate the core material.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Come on, give him a hard one.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: That was a hard one. All right. How does the flow rate in a pipe depend on its diameter? You don’t know, do you? What’s the matter, smart guy? Don’t know Poiseuille’s law?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (coughing several times)
utterance.content: Thank goodness I got it. Now I can quit checking my stool.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Okay, what are the potential side effects for our erectile dysfunction drug?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Headaches, dizziness and nausea.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Those are also the side effects of having a 75-year-old man with an erection climb on top of you.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Want to stop here?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Uh, no. I can keep going.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Nah, you got this. Let’s go for a drink. I’ll call Amy.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, good. She seemed like she really wanted to go out tonight.

utterance.speaker: Amy (phone ringing, running down stairs from outside Penny’s door)
utterance.content: Hey, girl.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, next question, for the Butterfinger. How long is a galactic yea

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: 250 million years.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay, this one is for a Cadbury Creme Egg.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh! It’s not even Easter time. This is crazy.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Which Archimedean solid has 20 regular triangular faces, 30 square faces, 12 pentagonal faces, 60 vertices and 120 edges?

utterance.speaker: All together
utterance.content: The Rhombicosidodecahedron.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: We are so smart.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Why didn’t girls like us in high school?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Because we were awkward and weird and couldn’t play sports!

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Right again.
